I had the Mongolian Beef, which surprised me because it was missing the usual spicy strands of green onion and red peppers.  It was sitting on top of these white, crispy fried noodles, which I think was originally intended to add bulk and serve as decoration for the dish, but the noodles absorbed the yummy brown sauce and provided a nice contrast to the soft strips of beef.
author: Tom K.

description: Went to lunch here recently. Very well priced lunch selection come with soup & rice. Delicious hot & sour soup ! really must rave about soup and Hunan fish entree...fresh, well sized portion and lovely decor. I'm a fan
author: Jas S.

description:
Food at Alice's is not your typical MSG filled Chinese food. It's the same as Eric's on Church, but it's always less busy (they deny this fact for some reason tho - but, take at takeout menu and compare to Erics!).

My only problem is that the food is less spicy than I typically like my Chinese food. But, other wise, this place is pretty good. And, if you want soups, I really think they do an awesome job with all of the ones that I've tried.
author: Dan M.

description:
Average, but not bad, Chinese food. Definitely several steps above hot-plate.  It's your typical American-Chinese place.  

As many people have commented, Alice's is more or less a clone of Erik's down the street.  If you want a quieter meal, Alice's in the place to do.  

Some people have said the service at Erik's is unfriendly.  I don't think it's that so much as Erik's is usually a lot busier.  The food, however, is almost identical, so you should decide based on parking and whether you want a louder or quiter meal.
author: Tullia F.

description:
You can have anything you want at Alice's restaurant... provided that you want un-fresh, un-tasty, un-spicy, uninspired food.

Was I in an alternate Alice's than the rest of you?

This place was bad. I mean BAD. I mean "we didn't eat enough food to get full because the food was inedibly bad"-bad. The mapo tofu was bland (this is rated spicy on the menu?) and the tofu was like cardboard. The potsticker wrappers were thick and gummy, the crispy side was somehow burnt and soggy at the same time (hm, reheated?), and the chicken in the General Tso's tasted distinctly freezer-burned. Even the rice was soggy and sad. They boxed up our leftovers without our asking, and we dumped them into a neighbor's trash on the way home. Yuck.

Eric's isn't good, but at least it will do in a pinch if you don't want anything authentic or interesting. This isn't even that good.

The decor is nice, though it seems caibrated to impress the sort of diner who would say "Oh, this place is NICE. I hate dirty restaurants... This one is so clean! And I hate walking through the kitchen to use the bathroom..."
author: anita c.

description: I live literally right beside Alice's and while it is kind of americanized for chinese food it is downright delicious!  I love all their vegetarian options and the people who work there are very friendly.  I hardly ever eat-in, for the most part I order for pickup, and unlike most places their to-go portions are just as large as their eat-in portions and that is one of the things I love about this place.  My favorites there are their vegetarian fried rice (I always ask for it with no egg!), the vegetarian hot and sour soup, the sauteed green beans, or the green salad with tofu!  I have never had anything from there I didn't like, so if you haven't been there you should definitely check it out!
author: Morgan B.

description:
I have been going to Alice's forever, the taste, prep, quality, and service has never really changed... The lunch specials are a great way to go, and you get a good amount of food for the price.  But as far as quality chinese in the Noe Valley-Glen Park area goes, this place has been a stand-by of mine for a long time.  

My fave dishes include: Shrimp with Snow Peas entree, their Sizzling ice Soup, and the Smoked Pork.  YUM!!!!!
author: Miss F.

description: This place had really good food, except for the flavorless vegetable soup to kick-off my lunch special.  But that's nothing that a little soy sauce can't fix!  We had the orange-peel chicken and the sweet and sour rock cod.  They were both very flavorful, sweet AND SPICY.  Loved them both.  Nice atmosphere, super-friendly service, very neighborhoody feel.  Prices were very competitive.  But the real reason I am writing this review is so I can ask what the hell are those things displayed on the wall?  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/g4vf4bYFhvSmkWZn3DMt-g?select=xKlfnf74M0w55nxge8rUcg
author: Tim A.

description:
Something happened in my life recently where I have become intolerant of food with too much starch, grease, or too much of too much. I call it the fresh-yummy-SF-food effect. Or to be painstakingly honest with you, it's the IBS effect. 

I don't just get guilt about eating bad food, I double over and try to dial my mom's number on my cell phone. Naturally, I have learned to steer away from greasy Chinese. Both the mysteriously prepared authentic Chinatown version and the generic Mc-Chinese version. I have mostly not missed it, save for Chow Mein, the worst offender of my intestines.

But Alice's--she's different. She cares about me. She gives me fresh, spicy Chinese with veggies that snap! in your mouth and don't leave you praying to a neglected God for relief. 

Alice, baby, please open in my neighborhood.
author: Shannon V.

description:
My friend and I got extremely sick after eating Mango Chicken from here..

Looks like we weren't the only ones, I am filing a complaint with the health department

We spent 20 dollars just for one dish and one appetizer and our reward was getting food poisoning

Here is a copy of a recent health report that they received a very poor score on:

Score Violation type Degree of risk Date discovered Date abated Description
64 061 (CFR) VERMIN - Rodents/Roaches/Flies Low Risk 19-AUG-11 29-AUG-11 Food
  054 (CFR) Floors, Walls, Ceilings Improperly constructed, in disrepair, not clean Low Risk 19-AUG-11 29-AUG-11 Food
  049 (CFR) Wiping Cloths not clean/inadequate sanitizer turbid/not properly stored Low Risk 19-AUG-11 29-AUG-11 Food
  042 (CFR) Non Food Contact Surface Unclean Low Risk 19-AUG-11 29-AUG-11 Food

  019 (CFR) Inadequate/Inaccessible handwashing facilities & supplies Moderate Risk 19-AUG-11 29-AUG-11 Food
  016 (CFR) Lack of Food safety knowledge: no food safety certification Moderate Risk 19-AUG-11 29-AUG-11 Food
  009 (CFR) Food Contact surfaces not clean/sanitized High Risk 19-AUG-11 29-AUG-11 Food
  002 (CFR) Hands not clean/improperly washed/gloves improperly used High Risk 19-AUG-11 29-AUG-11 Food
author: Juanita M.

description:
We eat at Alice's often. The restaurant is very clean. The staff is always courteous and helpful. And the food is consistently delicious. We enjoy the sizzling rice soup - chocked full of fresh vegetables. The walnut prawns, the pot stickers and crab rangoon are our favorites. Alice's fried rice selections are cooked to perfection. Light, fluffy and perfectly balanced. 
This is a wonderful little neighborhood restaurant with very comfortable decor. We have never been disappointed.
author: Cody L.

description:
Reliable, quality chinese food.  Good for take out! 

Thumbs UP: Menu similar to Eric's on Church but no relation ( I dont belive it ),  fresh ingredients and consistant quality 
Thumbs DOWN: Staff could be a little friendlier.
author: Jeff C.

description:
I finally have a "go-to" Chinese restaurant in San Francisco.  I've been back  to Alice's several times now after a friend told me about it, and I've thoroughly enjoyed every dish I've tried so far.

Will-not-let-you-down dishes:
+Avocado egg rolls
+Veggie rolls
+Mongolian beef
+Spicy beef with garlic sauce
+Alice's spicy chicken
+Veggie mu shu

Service is also great...not too much attention, not too little attention either.
author: Pete S.

description:
Normally I'd pass this place off as a typical, boring SF Chinese restaurant.  It really doesn't come across as anything worth writing home about, and the menu is nothing spectacular.

However, one bite of their Shanghai Chicken and I was mesmerized.  Juicy glazed chicken served with crispy seaweed "noodles"?  Awesome.

The crab rangoon had a little too much cream cheese and not enough crab, and the ma po tofu was a little on the weak side.  I don't really like mushrooms in my ma po tofu, just tofu, pork and sauce.

That said, this place is right across the street from our place and I cannot wait to get the chicken again.
author: Tim C.

description: Best chinese food in the Bay area.  Clean and good service.. My favorite place...
author: Allan P.

description: I went here with friends because it was close. Good food. Not a destination restaurant. An average, clean, friendly Chinese joint with a name that made me think "Hey, can I really get anything I want?" Seriously, though. What's up with the names of Chinese restaurants along/near Church street?
author: David Z.

description: Food is above average.  But the great price, service, speed and clean environment launches Alice's to 5-star status in my book.  Ingredients always taste fresh.
author: Matt P.

description: Consistently better then Eric's.  Great food, cleaner, fresher tasting, well priced, good service, can always find parking.  There is never a wait for a table.  Great find in Noe Valley!
author: Craig A.

description:
Great pot stickers.  Super Sexy Hoisin String Beans.  Made my night!  Will go back for sure. 

If you eat here you will not be disappointed!
author: Dwayne A.

description:
I used to eat here often, many years ago and the food was good as was the service.  More recently my mother and I popped in for some lunch.  The place was 3/4 full, we quickly found our own table, sat down and were ready to order.  We sat for about 15 minutes.....finally a woman came over and asked (more like yelled) (and I quote) "WHAT YOU WANT??".  I guess this was her attempt at taking the order... My mother began to ask a question about the mixed vegetable plate on the lunch special, what type of vegetables did it have..she started to explain she has a heart prob..She was promply cut off by (and I quote)"BECHTABO, BECHTABO, IT SAY MIX BEVETABO", followed by eyes rolling.  Now she is practically yelling at my mother who is trying to explain that she cannot eat brocolli per doctors order.  At this point I step and and it wasn't pretty.  I cut her off and pointed out that she was being completely rude, I told her we wouldn't be eating here because she was soooo F*&king rude.  Suddenly she changed her tone to "Oh, what kind bechtabo you wan?" "Any kind okay, we can do, we can do".  Too late lady.  

As I said earlier I've been here many times in the past, the service was fine, the food was good, the prices were very good.  BUT, I don't need to put down good money to be treated like crap by some bitter hag.  If you are in the mood to be treated like crap then by all means check it out.  If not then go to Eric only a few blocks away with the exact same decor and menu...WTF??
author: Wendy S.

description: This is a perfect place for a lunch.  The room is open and light, the decor pleasant in an unforced way, and the service quick and efficient.  We had some succulent, crispy pot stickers, to-die-for avocado spring rolls, fried rice, and, in a moment of nostalgia, General Tso's chicken.  Everything was flavorful, fresh, and precisely cooked.  We haven't been there for dinner, but have enjoyed several lunches and look forward to more.
author: Bruce A.

description: I LOVE Alice's.  Their Mango Chicken is my favorite!!!!  Service is good and I've never had to wait for a table.  I've never had a bad meal here and everything is fresh and cooked just the way it should be.
author: Karen C.

description: My husband and I are thinking that Yelp steered us wrong for a change.Tonight we got a shrimp curry and the shrimps were mealy, tasted as though they were frozen. I've got a icky feel from having eaten that one shrimp. Never had such a disgusting shrimp. Ewww. The Mu Shu lacked flavor.  Cannot recommend. Avoid. Nothing redeeming.
author: BETH T.

description:
Pretty good chinese food in a nice atmosphere. There are a couple of places that the food is a little better- but lets face it- I dont necessarily want to sit down and have dinner in them.

The orange chicken has good flavor, but its a bit dry.
Asparagus yummy, chicken chow mien excellent, kung pao dishes spicy and the helpings are generous.

The price point is good and your food is ready fast!
author: Melissa B.

description:
Nothing like being Yelp reviewer #58, eh?   

Alice's is what I consider "safe" Chinese food.  It's where you take your relatives from out of town, or friends who don't want to be particularly adventuresome in Chinese food.  

Having said that, the Shanghai chicken with chopped up seaweed and pine nuts if very tasty.   The orange beef was as well if a bit overcooked, making the beef strips more like beef jerky.

Service was attentive which hasn't always been the case when I've eaten there before.

The collection of art glass is fun to look at while you wait for your dishes to be served.
author: Scott S.

description:
We went here for lunch the other day...

They have a lot of specials.. all very affordable... 6 bucks and it includes soup...

The restaurant is clean... bright... Our waiter was really nice... 

The parking is a real problem if you go at night... It can be depressing...

We will go back...
author: Joe B.

description:
Alice's has taken a downhill turn over the past couple years.  We used to order take out all the time and totally enjoy it (but didn't enjoy Alice's scowls and moodiness when we picked up our food).  As for dining in, the service has always been really impersonal and borderline rude.  

The last couple times we've ordered, the food has been seriously greasy, over-sauced, and unpleasant.  I swear, I feared that I would wake up with a full face of acne due to the grease factor. What happened, Alice?!
author: Abby W.

description:
If you're looking for Chinese food that delivers solid dishes every time without the hustle & bustle of Eric's then Alice's is the place for you. I've been there about a dozen times and I always walk away with a smile on my face. 

Alice's spicy eggplant is incredible. Its wedges of eggplant served with a bunch of shrimp & chicken in an amazing spicy sauce. The flavors are so spot on we can't go here without ordering it. Its one of those dishes that just talking about it anytime, day or night, makes you want to go eat it... MMmmm. Spicy Eggplant...

I'm a big egg roll snob and to be honest the first time I tried them here I wasn't very impressed, but they grow on you. The crispiness & veggies are all great but they put cinnamon in them so that really took some getting used to. I wouldn't order them particularly but they come with the combo platter which is a great way to start.

The walnut prawns are sinfully good too, I'm sure they're completely unhealthy and probably take days off your life but its worth it for those crispy sweet little buggers.

I've tried a bunch of other dishes and they all range from decent to fantastic. Some of the more interesting flavor combo's (Orange Beef?) don't quite tango with my flavor pallet but I've discussed with others who go nuts.

Everyone thinks Alice's is Eric's is Aliza's but they've all got their own variations and are all worth visiting - the plus with Alice's is that you also save a buck or five.
author: Jeff S.

description: Good food. Friendly and fast. Something eerily similar to Eric's around the corner and a few blocks down, but somehow it tastes better.  I have only ever eaten take-out, so I have little to say about the service other than that they are fast and have yet to screw up an order.
author: Eric H.

description:
Yes, I also think that Eric's and Eliza's and Alice's are all the same scene. They have the same food and the same flatware... Anyway, I like Alice's best as its a restaurant where there shouldn't be a restaurant. Its in the middle of a sleepy Noe neighborhood and has nicer staff. 

That said, food is OK. Its typical and tasty.
author: A W.

description: Always tasty, and very rarely so crowded that you have a long wait.  Alice's is every bit as good as Eric's, with less difficult parking and friendlier staff.
author: Linda G.

description:
The best Chinese restaurant I've ever been to, and I've been to lots. No one can match their Orange Beef or Orange Chicken -- it's unparalleled. Everyone else's Orange Chicken/Beef = just can't hold a candle. It's like meat candy. I can't crow about it enough. I'm craving it just writing this!

Also love the Shanghai Chicken -- delicious, different, more-ish, savory, nutty. My husband gets the King Salmon with Garlic Sauce, which is heavenly delicious. The Alice's Cakes are scrumptiously decadent. Even just their Chicken with Mixed Vegetables is a step above.

Always consistently good, every time.
author: Brooke H.

description: this is always my go to neighborhood Chinese spot.  always good.  always has a friendly staff.  love it.
author: Helpful S.

description: I used to live on the same block as Alice's and so I had either their mango chicken or walnut prawns every week. It's very clean and pretty and their take-out service is quick. The parking and the wait are better than Eric's since it's not right on Church St.
author: Liz O.

description: This is my favorite place for Chinese in San Francisco (and, yep, it's in Noe Valley!)  The food is always cooked just right and served hot.  On this trip there was a private party for 40 there.  I was concerned that the kitchen wouldn't be able to "keep up" with all of the goings on, but I was wrong.  Our appetizers (Potstickers) came right out.  As soon as we finished them our main dishes (Moshu pork, General Tso's chicken and the house combination rice) came out just as fresh and hot as usual.  Well done!  Will be back next trip.
author: Dave E.

description:
Went in early...600pm.  Less than half of the tables were occupied. We ordered three dishes plus rice.  The first one took 45 minutes. After we finished it we sat for another 30 minutes and then they came to clear off the table.  Uh, still waiting for two more dishes. Another 20 minutes and here they come and were plopped on the table.  

I've eaten here once before and the food this time was tasteless, unlike the first time.

Never any refills of beer or water offered. Had to ask for the check and again plopped on the table. No apology, no thank you, nothing.

It was obvious that they were short handed, only two wait persons. It is Valentine's Day...which common sense tells you it will most likely be busy, but at least apologize for service failures...and a thank you is not asking too much.

Total dining time for 2 people:  2 hours and 10 minutes.

I will NEVER eat here again.
author: Jack L.

description: I went with 3 other people and everyone liked their food a lot.  We had two different prawn dishes, chicken, and vegetarian.  The servers were very nice and the atmosphere was relaxed.
author: Lily B.

description:
Service: 3.5/5
Food: 3.5/5
Wait: 4/5
Price: $
Presentation of food: 3/5
Presentation of restaurant: 4/5
Overall: 3.5/5

Thee boyfriend and I came here last night to try this place out because we we're feeling Chinese. We arrived around 9:40ish pm and didn't realize they we're about to close because the OPEN sign was still lit, we walked in and the waitress warned us ahead of time if we can order a little quicker because Kitchen is closing. I'm surprised they still took our order, so that was really nice of them. We hurried and ordered their Alice Fried Rice, Alice Chow Mein, and Beef w/ Broccoli. The Fried Rice wasn't really what I prefer, the way they cooked it was WITHOUT Soy Sauce, so they use either Salt or MSG instead. I feel weird eating Fried Rice w/o Soysauce, and i didnt wanna add soysauce myself because the dish was salty enough. My Chowmein was good, except that there was a lot of stuff on there, kind of overwhelming. But i did love how the noodles are the thick noodles i liked and the sauce was good, just a little too much sauce for me personally. The Beef w/ Broccoli wasn't too bad, except we didn't order any White Rice with it cuz we had Fried Rice; so if you order this, be sure to order white rice NOT FRIED rice. lol.
author: Eva H.

description: We really enjoyed the mango chicken and spicy eggplant dishes after reading tips from other Yelpers. Service was speedy and I like how they leave a ceramic pot of tea at your table. Will definitely return!
author: Justin M.

description:
As a 15 year Noe Valley resident, this is the best  and ONLY Chinese take-out (or sit-down) that I even consider!  

When my family visits from out-of-town, they INSIST upon Alice's.

Favorites:  The seafood medley, orange-peel beef, and of course, the (decadent) walnut prawns!  Oh, and don't forget "Alice's: special fried rice"...yumm...
author: hugh c.

description: It's a toss-up between Eric's and Alice's. However I do feel that it's easier to get in and out at Alice's. Overall their fried crab ragoons are amazing. Great for take-out if in the area.
author: Eric S.

description: Terrific lunch specials. I had the garlic chicken special, which included hot tea, rice, and soup. The meal was only around $7.00, and the service was excellent!
author: Kurt H.

description: The closest restaurant to my house also makes some damn fine Chinese food.
author: Mark C.

description: With Firefly and Shanghai 1930 closed, we just played a bet and went. Off the hook good. The shrimp were so good, I ate the whole order. The fried rice had some nice veggies in it, served very fresh and hot. And the rest of the food on the table - mu shu, Orange Chicken, etc.. were all amazing. Well worth a 30 minute drive into the city. Next time I want to leave room for Michele's Ice Cream, but the food was so good, I didn't want to waste it.
author: Richard M.

description: Great Chinese food at a great price. Can't ask for much else. Place is low-key enough to bring the kids without any issues which is a plus for me.
author: Mark F.

description: It was just "fine" Chinese food. Nothing spectacular, but nothing terrible. We ordered beef with broccoli (decent, though not the best pieces of beef), chicken chow mein, moo shoo chicken (good), and hot & sour soup (probably the best thing we ordered).
author: Sally M.

description: After two years of frequenting Eric's, I decided today to see what all the VS is about. I popped in for their lunch special and pretty much found it to be very similar.  The service might have been slightly friendlier and it was a tad bit less crazy in there.  I think I might switch it up now and start coming here instead, see how it goes.  My alligence is to neither/both.
author: e w.

description:
I only give it  a one star because very recently I noticed a large cockroach on a table in the restaurant.

Been eating hear for years and never saw this problem, but I feel if there is one in the restaurant then there must be more near the food source which is the kitchen.

I hope the owner reads this review and brings in a professional to rid the restaurant of the pest problem.

Nice staff and good food. Too bad about the problem.
author: Rob M.

description: Decent, quick and cheap. Nothing spectacular, but good and I expected that going in.
author: Nicole L.

description: This is one of our go-to places for a quick mid-week dinner with the kids.  I wouldn't necessarily call it authentic Chinese food but I mean that in a good way.  It's not too greasy and I don't get an MSG headache after I eat there.  The service is fast and the food is always fresh and cooked to perfection.  We have frequented Alice's for the past 12 years and have never had a bad experience.
author: Julie D.

description: I love Alice's. Their food is absolutely delicious. Typical Chinese food always has something in it that I'm kinda like... what did I just put in my mouth? Was that chicken or a hunk of fat? Alice's is not like that. Their meat is trimmed and cooked to perfection! If you want good Chinese food... go here!
author: Meghan K.

description: Alice's is distantly related to Eric's, probably some big family drama...not sure about Eliza's.  The big difference is that I have never seen Eric's or Eliza's place rice back into the big pot after it's been on the table.  At another visit, I accidentally bit into a big piece of MSG (didn't even know it came in solid form).  I see these two incidences as isolated, as this place is always pretty full and I can't imagine that people would be back if they regularly bit into MSG or saw rice being put back into the big serving pot.  But for me it will be Eric's from now on; their staff is way nicer and food is similar, but better.
author: Lulu H.

description: Good if you want Chinese without MSG and healthy options like brown rice.  I doubt the food is very authentic, but it's consistently good.  They're friendlier at this location than Eliza's (Potrero Hill), and the presentation and cooking is inferior.  Eliza's cooking is more refined, but I still don't go there as much (less convenient location for me, and grumpy or apathetic wait staff).  One of the waiters is so sweet and shy, I have to tip extra when I'm there (even for takeout).  Alice's Spicy Eggplant is a don't miss dish and Mango Beef can be fun.
author: Jennifer L.

description: The food is ok but pricey. It seems better if you eat there versus take-out. That is probably because after you've fought for 40 minutes looking for parking, you're hungry and need some sustenance before the 20-mile hike back to your car.
author: Kevo M.

description: I happen to think the food at Alice's is pretty darn tasty.  They have some of the best pot stickers I've tasted anywhere in the world.  And the service is always friendly and perfect.  But here's my big, big, big problem with Alice's:  some of the customers there are disgusting, snot-nosed pigs.  Every single solitary time I dine-in at Alice's, I inevitably encounter some customer who is so affected by the spicy food that he/she must blow his/her nose into a napkin while sitting in the dining room. Yum!  My egg drop soup and the gelatinous sauce on my lemon chicken become so much more appetizing when I listen to a repulsive pig blow snot into a paper napkin.  I'm not a very squeamish guy, and I try not to get hung up on archaic forms of politeness, but, my god, I draw the line at snot blowing in a dining room.  Where does it end?  Is it ok for me to pull out my kid's potty chair and let him take a dump at the table?  Can I just go ahead and vomit mid-meal if I need to?  Ok to clean out Uncle Jim's catheter during the appetizers?  How about watching my sister change her tampon before dessert?  Is zit popping ok while we enjoy our tea?  Yeah, my nose sometimes runs because of the deliciously spicy goodness at Alice's, but, you know what, I duck into the bathroom or out onto the sidewalk if I've gotta blow my nose.  And there's also the amazingly simple option of not ordering spicy food if i know it might affect the production of mucus in my nasal cavity.  Now, if I were the esteemed owner of Alice's, I'd probably politely ask nose-blowers to do their snot expelling in the bathroom or on the sidewalk, and if they didn't follow those instructions, I'd toss their sorry butts out the door and 86 them evermore, but that'd probably hurt people's feelings and hurt business too--I guess there's a good reason why I'm not a restaurateur.  So, here's how I deal with the veritable snot-fest at Alice's:  I no longer dine-in at Alice's--yep, it's all take-out all the time for me.  But be forewarned:  if I'm ever at Alice's picking up some take-out to enjoy at home in my own snot-free dining room, and I'm subjected to your blowing your nose at your table, I'm gonna walk right over to you and spew some type of my bodily fluids or some excreta onto your plate--even if you're eating those delicious, world-class Alice's pot stickers.
author: clover s.

description: Great American-Chinese food.  Local haunt.  Reasonable prices and consistently good.  They don't kick you out (at least when they are not busy) with rings fantastic in my book!
author: M W W.

description: One of the best Chinese restaurants in San Francisco. Don't  miss their orange beef. It is excellent!!!!
author: Michele M.

description: The lunch specials have the nice price ($5.25).  Check out the GIANT won-ton soup.  Tons of fresh mushrooms.  It's the most elaborate I've seen.
author: Big Stu L.

description: love alice's:) u can always get a table, hardly a wait. lovely and clean restaurant, reminds me alot of regent thai. food is very good and service is great! parking can be a little tough but most of the time its ok. really great and chinese food, love the kung pao prawns!
author: vicki g.

description: Solid Chinese food, not expensive (although not cheap).  Well lit.  Decent service.  I would come here if for some reason I was craving Chinese and stuck in Noe and couldn't get to the Inner Sunset to eat at San Tung (mmmm...).  Favorite dish:  eggplant something.  Don't get the avocado spring rolls (it sounded good when we were starving and ordering, k?).
author: S J.

description: Pretty darn good food, had a few bites but was happy w/ their selection of dishes. I went here for a dinner for a bday event and was definitely satisfied.
author: Ryan M.

description: There is  has not been a wait whenever I have gone. the food is good and not greasy like some chinese food. I love the hot and sour soup. I am not sure if it is like Erics but whatever I think it is better. Not all of the food is fried and at erics it is ready in two seconds which kind of scares me. The pot stickers are good as well as the orange shrimp.
author: Carli M.

description: Went to Alice's for the first time yesterday and while the food was fresh, it was too bland for my taste.  The Schezwan pork was decent but will not win any awards.  The string bean dish and the soup were both very bland and forgettable.
author: Shawn H.

description:
I love this restaurant!  The service is great and the food is plentiful and tastes great!  I'm a bit partial for their Hunan Prawns...a great spicy sauce and crunchy with large prawns.  I usually order it less spicey, but great either way!
It's a wonderful place to go for lunch, even if you want to dine alone with a good book and a glass of wine.
A wonderful neighborhood restaurant!
author: D A.

description:
We read the reviews and thought this place would have more potential than Eric's in Noe, but unfortunately Alice's disappointed as well. 

Their egg rolls and corn soup were average. However, the main dishes we got (string beans/bean curd, spicy chicken and basil) were very sub-par. Chinese food should never be drenched in salty "brown sauce!" Whoever invented this type of "chinese" food?

I grew up eating asian food so maybe I am too picky, but I know I will never eat at any Chinese food restaurant again in Noe (I gave them all a chance!) - - I'll have to go elsewhere. Sorry Alice's! I wanted to like you!

On the plus side, the waiting staff are all very courteous, attentive, and nice. Their restaurant is also clean and well-lit.
author: E M.

description: The food is inexpensive and plentiful.  I was there on a Saturday night and the place was nearly empty, but they must have put out almost 20 take out orders while I was there.
author: Matt W.

description: Alice's is not better than Eric's. They are one in the same. It's a philosophical conundrum.
author: G J J.

description: It's a tough choice but I have to give the slight edge to Eric's over Alice's, just more flavorful food, although you really can't go wrong at either, and Alice's is always less crowded.
author: Peter H.

description: I went here this past weekend with Sergio and my dad.  The food was so awesome!  I loved the family style and the service was great.
author: Rob P.

description: The hot sour soup was yummy, but the best item we ordered was the sesame beef - it was really good!!! We also ordered noodles and a shrimp dish...everything was pretty good. It's close to me so I am going back!!
author: Z A.

description:
We have given all the Chinese restaurants in our 'hood a try and definitely think Alice's is the best! We like Henry's also, but kind of think most of the dishes there taste the same.  

At Alice's, a couple of our absolute favorites for take out are:

*Mu-Shu Vegetables! 
*Sizzling Rice Soup!
author: L S.

description: Alice's lunch menu is quite a deal...you begin with a bowl of soup and then you are served is perfectly sized portion of rice and your desired entree.  I also love the feel of this restaurant: bright, open and airy (so different from many chinese restaurants) and the food is always good. Their won ton soup is very fresh and delicious...that actually sounds good right now...I think I'll go get me some...
author: Karen B.

description:
the big debate is alice looks like erics look like elizas -good or maybe it is okay they look like each other--the food varies between names.  i like Alices and Elizas but always find myself going back to Erics.  and the "crowds" at Erics are manageable.  

Buen Provecho!
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: Ate here a few years ago, and still remember the experience. After ordering appetizers, we found that there was hair in not one, but several of the items. I'm not going to knock them for that, I mean, stuff happens, right? But we pointed out one of the hairs and they were totally unapologetic. And when they brought the plate back, it was clear that it was the same plate, and they had just picked out the hair that we showed them...but not the rest! We had lost our appetite by then and no longer wanted the rest of our lunch. And they still charged us for the appetizer. Definitely won't go back.
author: L G.

description: The best Hot n' Sour soup in the City; it's like medicine for a cold.  The food is great, too, and the high ceilings and big windows make it a nice place to sit.  However, the owner, "Alice" is a cartoon character of a nasty horrible greedy boss; she has been known to steal tips as small as a dime away from her staff, who are gentle, kind and kinda scared, so try to slip a tip when she's not looking and they'll look at you with poignantly grateful eyes.
author: Carma K.

description: So so Chinese... it is walking distance from where I live. Will only go if I really deparate for Chinese and want it quick. Nothing too special about this place.
author: Ervinna L.

description: Decent chinese food in a nice neighborhood.
author: Dani D.

description: I used to do takeout from here years ago. I can't tell if this place has gone downhill or if I'm just much more picky about Chinese food now. It's pretty cheap and that's about the best thing I can say. I'm sure that I'll be back (because it's three blocks from my house), but very average food and very below average atmosphere.
author: Jason Y.

description: A Chinese restaurant favorite in San Francisco. I'm picky when it comes to Chinese food and I've never had a reason to get squeamish at Alice's. The chicken dishes are tasty, never any chewy bits, and the pot stickers are great. Nice neighborhood (Noe Valley) but parking can take a few minutes.
author: Alden C.

description:
not your typical chinese restaurant.  it's more new style where they don't cook with a heavy hand of oil.  

3.5 stars
author: Will I A m.

description: So this place is literally two blocks from my house, and the closest to me. It is very consistent, but I have been there on occasion to sit down and there are a few dishes to avoid (the ma-pu tofu comes to mind). Otherwise, most of the other dishes are decent and I am very happy with the establishment.
author: Hans H.

description: The Chinese food here is mediocre.  I ordered the chicken and basil plate but it came with mostly water chestnuts.  There was barely any chicken or basil in it.  The dish was still tasty and flavorful but I walked out still hungry for more chicken.  The reason I gave it 3 stars is because of the service and the option of having brown rice instead of white.
author: Toni C.

description: I'm really confused about the number of Chinese restaurants in SF that are named with basic English names like Alice's.  Where I grew up we went to places called Sun Ming, Imperial Wok, Lum's, Grand Sichuan.  But, alas, in SF we have Eric's, Eliza's and Alice's.  Of them, I vote Alice for President.  The food, although very basic, is consistently flavorful and reliable.
author: Jeff P.

description: Its good food. I've been told that the soup is really good, but I haven't tried it.
author: doug d.

description: I have been here several times, and I guess I keep going back because the food is delicious. The ladies are really friendly, but once again, I think its because the company I go with are frequent visitors. But, the food, and I have gotten something different each time is delicious, and there is typically no wait, but the service is prompt. Go try it!
author: Jenna R.

description: good fresh chinese food  for what it is i think alice's is a hit.  mango chicken.  yum.  quick, cheap, easy, good with kids, service is amazingly fast and they're always pleasant.  eat in or take out.  yup.  glad they're around:)
author: Sarah P.

description:
The minute I walked in, I felt that it would be a nice surprise.  The service was nice, the food was good.  They were nice about my baby making a fuss.
Potstickers were great, soup was nice.  The portions were generous.  The decor was good and made me feel that it was not cheapo restaurant even though the price was very good.
Highly recommended!
author: Miinno N.

description: Alice's used to be one of my favorite Chinese restaurants in SF. Now the only tasty things are the fortune cookies. What a pity!
author: D'Andy C.

description: I felt like copying my review for Eric's and just substituting the names. We go here for the mango prawns, sesame beef and stir fried green beans with tofu. But then again, that's what we order at Eric's. I think the atmosphere is what makes it a different restaurant. A lot more laid back, definitely more out of the way - and, may be just far enough from the Noe Valley PTA and their brats to make it a totally different experience.
author: Rey L.

description: We used to live in Noe Valley and were so lucky to be just blocks from this restaurant.  Nearly every week, we enjoyed Alice's food.  Now we are down in Redwood City but we still make sure to get the yummy Alice Cakes and Shanghai Chicken at least once a month.
author: Kate S.

description:
I've been to Alice's twice and I really wanted to like this place since I practically live across the street, but unfortunately the place isn't for me.  The food isn't bad, but I guess it just isn't my style.  The first time I ordered the mu shu vegetables, and I believe instead of serving it with crepes, they actually gave me flour tortillas.  There is nothing wrong with tortillas, but I was really looking forward to those thin Chinese crepes.  On the second visit I decided to play it safe and ordered the vegetable soup and that wasn't even good.  Too salty and bland and the veggies were seriously lacking.  

I guess I'll have to trek down to Yuet Lee when I'm craving for Chinese.
author: Rachel J.

description: a favorite that is worth leaving your neighborhood for. Parking is easy and the food and service consistently good. their ingredients are extremely fresh and of high quality. don't miss the Hunan smoked pork, alice's spicy chicken, mango tofu, and a host of other delectable dishes. a veritable bargain.
author: John T.

description: Their entrees are good but I must say I did not like the wonton soup very much. The service is usually pretty good, the orange wedges are great after the meal. I've had Cashew & Brocolli Chicken, Cashew & Brocolli Prawns, Fried Rice, and their must-have Pot Stickers.
author: Gabriela R.

description: I don't mean to be unkind, but anyone who gives this place a good review simply has not had the pleasure of having good chinese food.  This is not just so so, but really really bad.  Even if I had spent 1/2 the amount I did for Walnut Prawns (a house specialty) spring rolls and rice I would have still felt ripped off.  Spring rolls...greasy, bad tasting plain awful.  Walnut Prawns.. I just don't get it.  prawns battered and deep fried and seasoned with what I would guess to be mayonaise?? served in a "basket" of fried something that was totally inedible over 4 little pieces of a bitter green with 1/2 slice of lemon too thin to squeeze for juice and finally (get this) a marchino cherry?  I'm sorry I don't get it.  Just a really really bad culinary experience.  The best part of the meal was the white rice, with a little tamari (soy sauce) was by far the best part of the meal.  Two stars was being generous.  New York Chinatown where are you when I need you, for that matter ANY place on clement street is much much better than Alice's.   Noe Valley you have million dollar homes why can't you get good Chinese food.
author: Art B.

description: I started going to Alice's in Noe Valley when I live around the corner on day street. Now I am there every Sunday like it's a religion. The place is very clean, the wait staff is very helpful and the food tops it all. Normally when I eat Chinese food I feel very heavy after, but at Alice's it's perfect. The best thing about it though is that you can have 5 dishes for about $35.00 for two! WOW can you beat that anywhere else?  Keep up the good work and see you on Sunday!
author: BOB M.

description: This is the best Chinese food in town for non-Chinese people. I mean it is a sort of westernized menu, is all. The Shrimp with portobello mushrooms is magnificent. My friend and I have a long standing feud about which is better: Eric's or Alice's? I know Eric's (around two blocks away) was there first, and Alice's copied the formula, but I feel that Alice's is an improvement on the original! Please let me know your thoughts. My friend thinks Alice's is declasse, whatever that means.
author: Ben B.

description: for those of you who were not fans and also eat meat, please go back and try the sesame beef. it is insanely genius. please
author: Hillary R.

description: The only reason that I have given them this many stars is because they are sooo much nicer then the a-holes at Eric's. The food is the same. However, I am now concerned about the roaches and the recycled rice.
author: Alulubeth O.

description: the food here is great i always have the mongolian beef is the best, potstickers, wonton soup are all really good im yet to have a dish from this place thats bad . the service is really good to try this place its great.
author: mike b.

description: i used to go at least once a week when i lived in noe, and now that i moved away i take every opportunity i am in the neighborhood to eat here. they should have alice's all of ther city :)
author: papa c.

description: Nothing to write home about, but it's reliable. The mango chicken (or mango tofu) is very good, and my husband adores the string beans with bean curd. The only truly bad dish I've had here is the chow fun. Normally, that's my favorite, but Alice's chow fun kind of tastes how my cat's breath smells. Yuck.
author: Hilary R.

description: Fresh food and great service at a very reasonable price. Everything is delicious but I highly recommend the orange chicken or mango prawns. Their mushu pork is wonderful and their pot stickers are a must. Try Alice's...you will not be disappointed.
author: G A.

description: We like this restaurant for Friday-night takeout -- food is excellent, and they always have it ready when they say they will.  Because it's so convenient for takeout (parking is relatively easy), we've actually never eaten in the restaurant, but it's always crowded when we come in.
author: Stephanie S.

description: Alice's has some great Chinese food. It's pretty clean and consistent. Great mushu, great potstickers, shanghai chicken and the list goes on. it's never too long of a wait and the owners are pretty rad. Way better than Eric's. I grew up in Noe Valley. You can trust me...go to Alice's if you want a salty chinese fix
author: Brianna M.

description: i'm going to echo Billy. its exactly the same. i read in a best of sf one year that it was the best restaurant inspired by a family feud. Its by far the best chinese in the city when it comes to parking. to the neighbors on sanchez I'll give you my apologies now.
author: David T.
